lg.l: AN old house, crumbling half away, all barnacled and lichenâgrown,
Of saddest, mellowest, softest grey,âwith a grand history of its ownâ
Grand with the work and strife and tears of more than half a thousand years.
Such delicate, tender, russet tones of colour on its gables slept,
With streaks of gold betwixt the stones, where windâsown flowers and mosses crept:
Wild grasses waved in sun and shade oâer terrace slab and balustrade.
Around the clustered chimneys clung the ivyâs wreathed and braided threads,
And dappled lights and shadows flung across the sombre browns and reds;
Whereâer the graverâs hand had been, it spread its tendrils bright and green.
Farâstretching branches shadowed deep the blazoned windows and broad eaves,
And rocked the faithful rooks asleep, and strewed the terraces with leaves.
A broken dial marked the hours amid damp lawns and garden bowers.
An old house, silent, sad, forlorn, yet proud and stately to the last;
Of all its power and splendour shorn, but rich with memories of the past;
And pitying, from its own decay, the gilded piles of yesterday.
Pitying the new race that passed by, with slighting note of its grey walls,â
And entertaining tenderly the shades of dead knights in its halls,
Whose blood, that soaked these hallowed sods, came down from Scandinavian gods.
I saw it first in summerâtime. The warm air hummed and buzzed with bees,
Where now the pale green hopâvines climb about the sere trunks of the trees,
And waves of roses on the ground scented the tangled glades around.
Some long fernâplumes drooped thereâbelow; the heaven above was still and blue;
Just hereâbetween the gloom and glowâa cedar and an aged yew
Parted their dusky arms, to let the glory fall on Margaret.
She leaned on that old balustrade, her white dress tinged with golden air,
Her small hands loosely clasped, and laid amongst the moss and maidenhair:
I watched her, hearing, as I stood, a turtle cooing in the woodâ
Hearing a mavis far away, piping his dreamy interludes,
While gusts of soft wind, sweet with hay, swept through those garden solitudes,â
And thinking she was lovelier eâen than my young ideal love had been.
Tall, with that subtle, sensitive grace, which made so plainly manifest
That she was born of noble race,âa cool, hushed presence, bringing rest,
Of one who felt and understood the dignity of womanhood.
Tall, with a slow, proud step and air; with skin half marble and half milk;
With twisted coils of raven hair, blueâtinged, and fine and soft as silk;
With haughty, clearâcut chin and cheek, and broad brows exquisitely Greek;
With still, calm mouth, whose dreamy smile possessed me like a haunting pain,
So rare, so sweet, so free from guile, with that slight accent of disdain;
With level, liquid tones that fell like chimings of a vesper bell;
With large, grave stagâeyes, soft, yet keen with slumbering passion, hazelâbrown,
Longâlashed and dark, whose limpid sheen my thirsty spirit swallowed down;â
O poor, pale words, wherewith to paint my queen, my goddess, and my saint!
You see that oriel, ivyâgrown, with the blurred sculpture underneath?
Her sweet head, like the Clytieâs own, with a white stephanotis wreath
Inwoven with its coiling hair, first bent to me in greeting there.
I shall remember till I die that night when we were introduced!
The great Sir Hildebrand stood byâher cousinâscowling as he used
To scowl if eâen a poor dumb cur ventured to lift his eyes to her.
I cared not. Well I knew her grace was not for him. I watched them dance,
And knew it by her lockedâup face, and her slow, haughty utterance.
I knew he chafed and raged to see how kind and sweet she was to me.
O dear old window!ânevermore the red and purple lights, that stray
Through your dim panes upon the floor on sunny summerânight, will lay
Soft rainbows on her glossy hair and the white dress she used to wear!
Those panes the ivy used to scratchâI hear it now when Iâm alone!
A pair of martlets used to hatch their young ones in the sculptured stone;
Those warm slabs were the bloodhoundâs bed, with fine yewâneedles carpeted.
The misselâthrushes used to search there for the berries as they fell;
On that high twig, at morn, would perch a shy and shivering locustelle,â
From yon low sweep of furzy brake, we used to watch it thrill and shake.
The banksia roses twined a wreath all round that ancient coat and crest,
And trailed the timeâworn steps beneath, and almost touched the martinâs nest;
The honey bees swarm swam in and out, and little lizards flashed about.
And when we flung the casement wide, the wind would play about her brow,
As she sat, etching, by my side,âI see the bright locks lifted now!
And such a view would meet our eyes of crimson woods and azure skies!
âTwas there, when fell the twilight hush, I used to feed her wistful ears,
And make her cheek and forehead flush, and her dark eyes fill full of tears,
With tales of my wild, fighting lifeâour bitter, brave Crimean strife.
We had, too, little concerts in that dear recess,âI used to play
Accompaniments on my violin, and she would sing âOld Robin Gray,â
And simple, tender Scottish songs of loyal love and royal wrongs.
My violin is dead for me, the dust lies thick upon the case;
And she is dead,âyet I can see eâen now the rapt and listening face;
And all about the garden floats the echo of those crying notes!
âTis a sweet garden, is it not? So wild and tangled, nothing prim;
No quaintâcut bed, no shaven plot, no stunted bushes, stiff and trim;
Its flowers and shrubs all overblown, its long paths moss and lichenâgrown.
âTwas on that terrace that we read the âIdylls,â sauntering up and down
With gentle, musing, measured tread, while leaves kept falling, gold and brown,
And mists kept rising, silverâgrey, one still and peaceful autumnâday.
In those long glades we roamed apart, and studied Spanish, and the tales
Of Chaucer,âthere we talked of art, and listened to the nightingales;
Eâen now, when summer daylight dies, I hear their bubbling melodies.
You see that bower, halfâhidden, made by the lowâbranching willowâtree?
We used to lounge there in the shade, and laugh, and gossip, and drink tea:
I wreathed her head with ferns, one night, and little roseâbuds sweet and white.
It grew my habit, byâandâby, to gather all the flowers she wore;
She used to take them silently, or I would leave them at her door,â
And wait about till she was drest, to see them nestling on her breast.
In that green nook she used to sit, and I would watch her as she worked.
Her face had such a spell in it, and such a subtle glamour lurked
In even motion of her hand!âwhy, I could never understand.
âTwas there I tied the little strap that held her netting down, one day,
And kissed the soft palm in her lap, which she so gently drew away.
Ay me, we held our tongues for hours! and I plucked off and ate the flowers.
She would not look at me at firstâI recollect it all so well!
Her delicate, downcast features, erst so pale, were tinted like a shellâ
Then like the petals that enclose the inmost heart of a moss rose.
The others came and chatted round, but we could laugh and chat no more;
I propped my elbow on the ground, and watched her count her stitches oâer;
Their talk I did not comprehend,âshe was too busy to attend.
The days passed on, and still we sat in our old place; but things were changed.
We were so silent after that!âso oddly formalâso estranged!
No more we met to worship art,âour little pathways branched apart.
All day I kept her face in viewâscarce one low tone I failed to hear;
And, though she would not see, I knew she felt when I was far or near.
Yet brief and seldom was the chance that gave me word, or smile, or glance.
One night I came home in the gloom. The other guests were mostly gone.
A light was burning in her room, and from the lawn it shone upon
I plucked a flower for her to wearâa white rose, fringed with maidenhair.
I passed through that long corridorâthose are its windows, to the westâ
That I might leave it at her door,âand saw her cross her threshold, drest.
No lamps were lit,âthe twilight shed a grey mist on her shiny head.
Her garments swept the oaken stairs; I stood below her, hushed and dumb;
She started, seeing me unawares, and stopped. âCome down,â I whispered; âcome!â
She waited, but I waited too;âand she had nothing else to do.
She came down, slowly, haughtily, with sweet pretence of carelessness.
I watched each step as she drew nigh, each brighter gleam on her white dress.
I did not speak, I did not stir, but all my heart went out to her.
She would have passed me, shy and still,âshe would not suffer herself to mark
That I was grown so bold, until I took her dear hands in the dark.
And thenâand thenââWell! she was good and patient, and she understood.
My arms were strong, and rude, and roughâbecause my love was so intense;
She knew the reason well enough, and so she would not take offence;
Though âtwas by force I made her stay, she did not try to get away.
Ah, then we had some happy hoursâsome blessed days of peace and rest!
This garden, full of shady bowers and lonely pathways, from whose breast
A thousand blending perfumes rise, became a very Paradise.
âTwas fair as the first Eden, then; and Adam had no fairer mate!
Nor grieved he more than I grieved, when the angel drove him from the gate.
When God cursed him from His high throne, He did not cast him out alone!
âTwas on that broken step we sat, where the yew branch is fallân and bent,
And read the Colonelâs letter, that recalled me to my regiment.
âTwas there, on such a night as this, I stood to give my parting kiss.
âTwas there I hugged the small Greek head upon my bosom, damp with dew;
âTwas there she soothed my grief, and said, âBut I shall still belong to you.â
O my sweet Eve, with your pure eyes!âyouâre mine now, in Godâs Paradise.
I sailed, you know, within a week, en route for Maltaâs heat and blaze;
And tender letters came, to speak of love, and comfort, and bright days.
I tried to think it was not hardâof what was coming afterward.
I used to dream, and dream, and dream, from night till morn, from morn till night;
My future life just then did seem so full, so beautiful, so bright!
I could not see, I could not feel, the sorrow dogging at my heel.
At length it touched me. Byâandâby the letters ceased. I looked in vain;
I roamed the streets dejectedly, and gnawed my long moustache in pain.
I wrote twiceâthrice; no answer still. Surely, I thought, she must be ill.
Until one evening Eyre came in, to lounge and gossip, drink and smoke,
I gave him leisure to begin; and, when his pipe was lit, he spoke,
Through curling vapour, soft and blueââGuy, Iâve a piece of news for you.
âOne of the girls you met last year at that poor tumbleâdown old placeâ
The darkâhaired oneâshe with the clear white skin and sweet Madonna face,â
Sheâs married now, I understand, to her rich cousin Hildebrand.â
I felt my limbs grow stark and stiff; I felt my heart grow cold as lead;
I heard Eyreâs quiet, musing whiffâthe noise swam round and round my head.
I veiled my eyes, lest he should see their passionate, mute misery.
âI only heard,â he said, âtoâday. Itâs out in all the papers, though.
She did not care for him, they say. But the old house was falling lowâ
Her fatherâs name and fame at stake. She would do anything for his sake.
âSome mortgages foreclosedâthe price of years and centuries of debt;
The manor doomed for sacrificeâor else the Lady Margaret.
Doubtless for Hildebrandâs red gold the rare Madonna face was sold.
âI fancy thatâs the history,â he ended, in a bitter tone.
âItâs not a new one, byâtheâbye.â And when he went, I sat alone,
And tried to ease me with a prayer, but ground my teeth in despair.
Then I grew stupid, numb, and tired. A fever crept through all my veins,
And wearied out my heart, and fired my dazed, tumultuous, teeming brains.
I hung suspended by a breath, for weeks and months, âtwixt life and death.
Then I recovered, and had leave to go to Englandâwhere she dwelt;
In my home climate to retrieve my broken health and strength. I felt
Twice ten years older than before. I knew I should come back no more.
Soon as I touched my native land, my feet turned toward the manor house.
They told me that Sir Hildebrand was in the Highlands, shooting grouse;
That she was in her fatherâs care. That night I found her, sitting there,
On that third step, just where the trees cast down their greenest, coolest shade;
Her weary hands about her knees, her head against the balustrade;
And such dumb woe in her sweet eyes, uplifted to the fading skies.
She did not see me till I burst through the roseâthickets round about.
She sprang up with a cry at firstâand then her arms were half stretched outâ
And then caught backward, for his sake. I felt as if my heart would break.
I knew the truth. I did not care. I did not think. I flung me down,
And kissed her hands, her wrists, her hair, the very fringes of her gown;
While she sat cowering in a heap, and moaned, and shook, but could not weep.
It was soon over. O good God, forgive me!âI was sorely tried.
âTwas a dark pathway that I trod; I could not see Thee at my side.
It was soon over. âI shall die,â she whispered, âif you stay here, Guy!
âO Guy! Guy! you were kind to me in our old days,âbe kinder now,â
Be kind, and go, and let me be!â And then I felt on my hot brow
The brush of her cold fingerâtipsâthe last soft contact of her lips.
And I obeyed her will and went, and vowed to tempt her nevermore.
I tried hard, too, to be content, and think of that which lay before.
I knew my dream of love was past, yet strove to serve her to the last.
I left my comradesâI had lost all taste for glory and for mirthâ
And, without hopes or aims, I crossâd the seas and wanderâd oâer the earth.
Without a light, without a guide, I drifted with the wind and tide.
My heart was broken when âtwas struck that bitter blow, and joy ran out!
Only a few stray treasures stuckâa few gleams flickered round about.
My old artâlove still lingered there,âI think that kept me from despair.
With strange companions did I dwell, one scorching summer, on the heights
Of Tangiersâ Moorish citadel, and mused away the days and nights.
With loose white garments and long gun, I roamed the deserts in the sun.
I painted Atlas, capped with snow, and lifted, cool, and still, and fair,
Out of the burning heat and glow, into the solemn upper air;
And Tetuanâs gleaming walls I drew on fields of Mediterranean blue.
I haunted Cairoâs crowded ways, and sketched carved doors and gilded grates,
Mosqueâdomes and minarets ablaze, and sweet dark heads with shining plaits;
And now a grave old Arab sheikh, and then a slim, straightâfeatured Greek.
In a swift wingâsailed boat I slid across the stream where Libya looms,
And from King Cheopâs pyramid saw Pharaohâcities, Pharaohâtombs;
And, stretching off for many a mile, the sacred waters of the Nile.
I saw the graves of mighty states,âI saw Thebesâ temple, overturnedâ
The City of the Hundred Gates, where Moses and Greek sages learned,
Where hungry lions prowl at noon, and hyÃ¦nas snarl at the bright moon.
I roamed through Nubian desert flats, where vultures sailed oâer burning seas;
And forests where the yellow bats hung, cloaked and hooded, from the trees;
And marshy wastes, where crocodiles slept on the shores of sandy isles.
I followed, through long days and nights, where, with their little ones and flocks,
Had passed the wandering Israelites; I read the writing on the rocks;
And eâen these restless feet of mine tracked holy feet in Palestine.
Roaming through Indiaâs burning plains, I chased wild boars and antelopes;
Swam brawling nullahs in the rains, and haunted dewâwet mangoâtopes;
Shot bears and tigers in the gloom of the dense forests of Beerbhoom.
Through swathingânets I watched at night the clear moon gild a palmâtree ledge;
And, through the flood of silver light, heard jackals at the compoundâhedge;
While punkahs waved above my head, and faint airs hovered round my bed.
I mused by many a sacred tank, where lonely temples fell away,
Where the fat alligators drank, and scarlet lotusâflowers lay;
Smoked curling pipes âneath roof and tree, the while dark nautchâgirls danced to me.
I trod the creeperânetted ground of deadly, beautiful, bright woods,
Where birds and monkeys chattered round, and serpents reared their crimson hoods.
I dwelt âneath breathless desertâglows, and Simlaâs Himalayan snows.
From the hot glades of garden reach, I wandered upward to Caboolâ
From the bright Hooghlyâs flowering beach to the wild mountains, calm and cool.
I wept at Cawnporeâs fatal well, and where our heroes fought and fell.
I roamed through Lucknowâs battered gateâthickâthronged with memories so intense!
And Delhiâs ruins of wild state and old Mogul magnificence.
I pressed the rank, bloodânurtured grass that creeps along the Khyber Pass.
I sailed the Irrawaddyâs stream, âmid dense teak forests; saw the moon
Light up with broad and glittering gleam the golden Dagun of Rangoonâ
The delicate, fretted templeâshells, whose roofs were rimmed with swaying bells.
In his gold palace, all alone, with square, hard face and eyes aslant,
I saw upon his royal throne the Lord of the White Elephant.
I mixed in wild, barbaric feasts with Buddhaâs yellowârobÃ¨d priests.
I crept with curious feet within imperial Chinaâs sacred bounds;
I saw the Palace of Pekin, and all its fairy gardenâgrounds;
The green riceâfields, the tremulous rills, the white azaleas on the hills;
The teaâgroves climbing mountain backs; the girlsâ rich robes of blue and white;
The cattle âneath the paddyâstacks; the gilt pagodas, tall and bright;â
And in a merchantâjunk I ran across the waters to Japan.
I saw, where silkâfringed mats were spread, within his laquered, bare saloon,
With his curled roofs above his head, on muffled heels, the great Tycoon.
Familiar things they were to meâthe pipes, and betelânuts, and tea.
I dug in Californian ground, at Sacramentoâs golden brim,
With hunger, murder, all around, and fever shaking every limb;
Saw, in lush forests and rude sheds, the Dyaks roasting piratesâ heads.
I shot white condors on the brows of snowy Andes; and I chased
Wild horses, and wild bulls and cows, oâer the wide Pampasâ jungleâwaste;
And saw, while wandering to and fro, the silver mines of Mexico.
In Caffre waggons I was drawn up lone Cape gorges, green and steep,
And camped by riverâgrove and lawn, where nightly tryst the wild things keep;
Where glaring eyes without the line of circling watchâfires used to shine.
I chased oâer sandy plains and shot the ostrich,âat the reedy brink
Of pools, the lion, on the slot of antelopes that came to drink;
Giraffes, that held their heads aloof âneath the mimosaâs matted roof;
And brindled gnus, and cowardly, striped shardâwolves, and âmid waterâplants
And flags, black hippopotami, and snakes, and shrieking elephants.
From courted sickness, hunger, strife, God spared my weary, reckless life.
In the bright South Seas did I toss through wild blue nights and fainting days,
With the snowâplumaged albatross. I saw Tahitiâs peaks ablaze;
And still, palmâfringed lagoons asleep oâer coral grottoes, cool and deep.
I built an Australian hut of logs, and lived aloneâwith just a noose,
A trap, a gun, my horse and dogs; I hunted longâlegged kangaroos;
And oft I spent the calm nightâhours beneath the gumâtreesâ forestâbowers.
I threaded miles and miles and miles, where Lenaâs sad, slow waters flow,
âMid silent rocks, and woods, and isles, and drear Siberian steppes of snow;
Where pines and larches, set alight, blaze in the dark and windless night.
I shot a wild fowl on the shore of a still, lonely mountain lake,
And, oâer the sheer white torrentsâ roar, heard longâdrawn, plaintive echoes wake;
Caught squirrels in their leafy huts, munching the little cedarânuts.
I trapped the small, soft sables, stripped the bloomy fur from off their backs,
And hunted grey wolves as they slipped and snuffed and snarled down reindeer tracks;
I brought the brown, bald eagle down from the white seaâhillâs rugged crown.
I saw the oilâlamp shining through the small and dim ice windowâpane;
And the near sky, so deeply blue, spangled with sparks, like golden rain;
While dogs lay tethered, left and right, howling across the arctic night.
I saw when, in my flying sledge, I swept the frozen tundraâslopes,
The white bears on some craggy ledge, farâoff, where ocean blindly gropes
In her dim cavesâwhere bones lie furled, the tokens of a vanished world.
I saw across the dread blue sky, spanning blue ice and bluer mist
(That shows where open waters lie), the bright Aurora keep her tryst,â
That arch of tinted flameâso fair! lighting the crystals in the air.
Then, all at onceâI know not whyâI felt I could no longer roam;
A voice seemed calling to my heartâReturn to England and thy home;
I found my thoughts were yearning yet, for one more glimpse of Margaret.
So on a sudden I returned. I reached the village in the night.
At one small inn a candle burned with feeble, pale, unsteady light:
The hostess curtseyed, grave and strange. She did not know me for the change.
My broad white brows were bronzed, and scarred with lines of trouble, thought, and care;
My young bright eyes were dim and hardâthe sunshine was no longer there;
My brown moustache was hid away in a great beard of ironâgrey.
âThe Manor House is habited,â to my brief question she replied.
âToânight my lady lies there dead. Sheâs long been ailing, and she died
At noon. A happy thing for her! Were you acquainted with her, sir?
âA sweeter lady never walked! So kind and good to all the poor!
She neâer disdained us when she talkedâneâer turned a beggar from her door.
Ah, sir, but we may look in vain; we neâer shall see her likes again.
âI heard the squireâs great bloodhoundâs bark; I woke, and shook, and held my breath.
My man, he stirred too in the dark. Said he to me, âMy ladyâs death
Is not far off. Another night sheâll never see.â And he was right.
ââTwas over in twelve hours or less. She lies there, on the golden bed,
In her old confirmation dress, with the small white cap on her head
Which bore the bishopâs blessing hand,âshe asked that of Sir Hildebrand.â
You see that window in the shade of those old beeches? âTwas that room
Wherein my dear dead love was laid. I climbed the ivy in the gloom
And silenceâjust once more to see the face that had belonged to me.
I stood beside her. No one heard. On the great rajahâs bed, alone
She lay. The nightâbreeze softly stirred the Cashmere curtains, and the moan
Of my wild kisses seemed to thrill the solitude. All else was still.
In the pale yellow taper light, I gazed upon her till the morn.
I see her nowâso sweet and white! the fair, pure face so troubleâworn!
The thin hands folded on her breast, in peace at last, and perfect rest!
NUMB, half asleep, and dazed with whirl of wheels,
And gasp of steam, and measured clank of chains,
I heard a blithe voice break a sudden pause,
Ringing familiarly through the lampâlit night,
âWife, hereâs your Venice!â
I was lifted down,
And gazed about in stupid wonderment,
Holding my little Katie by the handâ
My yellowâhaired stepâdaughter. And again
Two strong arms led me to the waterâbrink,
And laid me on soft cushions in a boat,â
A queer boat, by a queerer boatman mannedâ
Swarthyâfaced, ragged, with a scarlet capâ

Such painting as the chestnut bud
Shows in its opening heart;
Such lights as shine âtwixt earth and sky
When rainâclouds break apart;
Such soft, warm, subtle tints, as lie
In every mossy patchâ
On the blueâbrown trunks, now filled with life,
And the humble roof of thatch,â
In the purple hollows of the hills,
In the lichen on the wall,
In the orchard and the feathery woods,
And the sunâlit waterfall.
I like my humble country ways,
My simple, early meals;
I like to potter about the yard,
With my chickens at my heels.
Iâd rather climb this brambly steep,
Where freshest seaâwinds blow,
With my old straw hat hanging down my back.
Than canter along the Row.
To me (itâs vulgar, dear, I know)
No fÃªte is half so gay
As a cricketâmatch on the village green,
Or a picnic in the hay.
Ah, yes! Iâm happier as I am,â
Iâm ignorant, you see;
And the life of fashion that you love
Would never do for me.

div.head: âTHIS ENLIGHTENED AGE.â
A Meditation in the British Museum.

lg.l: I SAY it to myselfâin meekest awe
Of Progress, electricity and steam,
Of this almighty ageâthis liberal age,
That has no time to breathe, or think, or dream,â
I ask it of myself, with bated breath,
Casting a furtive glance about the hall,â
Our fathers, were their times so very dark?
Were they benighted heathens after all?
Had they not their GalileoâNewton tooâ
And men as great, though not a Stephenson?
Had they not passable scholars in fair Greece,
Who traced the paths we deign to walk upon
Had they not poets in those dismal daysâ
Homer and Shakespeare, and a few between?
Had they not rulers in their barbarous states,
Who scattered laws for our wise hands to glean?
Had they not painters, who knew how to paintâ
Raphael, to take an instanceâwell as we,
With near four hundred years of light the less?
Is Phidias matched in our great century?
And architects? Sure Egypt, and old Rome,
And ruined Athens tell of fair reputes!
The Pyramids, and temples of the Greeks,
May vie with our townâhalls and institutes.
Their marble Venice, with her dappled tints,
Their grey old minsters, strong as chiselled rocks,
Their Tyrolean castles, lifted high,
May outlast all our brickâandâmortar blocks.
And were there not refinements in those days,
And elegant luxuries of domestic life?
I read the answer in the precious things
Whereof these clustering cabinets are rife.
What can we show so beautiful in art?
What new of ours can match their wondrous old?â
This fragile porcelainâthis Venetian glassâ
This delicate necklace of Etruscan gold.
And was there not religionâwhen the Church
Was oneâa common motherâloved and feared?
When haughty souls rejoiced to bear her yoke?
When all those grand monastic piles were reared?
And were there not some preachersâChrysostoms,
Whose golden words still linger, like a chime
Of falling echoes in lone alpine glens,
Amongst the sonorous voices of our time?
And soldiersâheroes? Do we shame them much?
Have men more courage than in days of yore?
Are they more jealous for their manhood now?
Do they respect and honour women more?
Are they more noble than those good old knights,
Who scorned to strike a foe save in the faceâ
Who reckoned gold as dross to gallant deeds,
And counted death far happier than disgrace?
Is life more grand with us, who bask at ease,
And count that only excellent which pays,
Than âtwas to the stout hearts that wore the steel
In those dark, turbulent, fearless, fighting days?
O nineteenth century! God has given you light;
The morning has been spreadingâthat is all.
O liberal age! stoop your conceited head,
And gather up the crumbs that they let fall.
AN evening all aglow with summer light
And autumn colourâfairest of the year.
The wheatâfields, crowned with shocks of tawny gold,
All interspersed with rough sowthistle roots,
And interlaced with white convolvulus,
Lay, flecked with purple shadows, in the sun.
The shouts of little children, gleaning there
The scattered ears and wild blueâbottle flowersâ
Mixed with the cornâcrakeâs crying, and the song
Of lone wood birds whose motherâcares were oâer,
And with the whispering rustle of red leavesâ
Scarce stirred the stillness. And the gossamer sheen
Was spread on upland meadows, silver bright
In low red sunshine and soft kissing windâ
Showing where angels in the night had trailed
Their garments on the turf. Tall arrowâheads,
With flag and rush and fringing grasses, dropped
Their seeds and blossoms in the sleepy pool.
The waterâlily lay on her green leaf,
White, fair, and stately; while an amorous branch
Of silver willow, drooping in the stream,
Sent soft, lowâbabbling ripples towards her:
And oh, the woods!âerst haunted with the song
Of nightingales and tender coo of dovesâ
They stood all flushed and kindling âneath the touch
Of deathâkind death!âfair, fond, reluctant death!
A dappled mass of glory!
Harvestâtime;
With russet woodâfruit thick upon the ground,
âMid crumpled ferns and delicate blue harebells.
The orchardâapples rolled in seedy grassâ
Apples of gold, and violetâvelvet plums;
And all the tangled hedgerows bore a crop
Of scarlet hips, blue sloes, and blackberries,
And orange clusters of the mountain ash.
The crimson fungus and soft mosses clung
To old decaying trunks; the summer bine
Drooped, shivering, in the glossy ivyâs grasp.
By day the blue air bore upon its wings
Wideâwandering seeds, pale drifts of thistleâdown;
By night the fog crept low upon the earth,
All white and cool, and calmed its feverishness.
And veiled it over with a veil of tears.
The curlew and the plover were come back
To still, bleak shores; the little summer birds
Were goneâto Persian gardens, and the groves
Of Greece and Italy, and the palmy lands.
A Norman tower, with moss and lichen clothed,
Wherein old bells, on old wormâeaten frames
And rusty wheels, had swung for centuries,
Chiming the same soft chimeâthe lullaby
Of cradled rooks and blinking bats and owls;
Setting the same sweet tune, from year to year,
For generations of true hearts to sing.
A wide churchyard, with grassy slopes and nooks,
And shady corners and meandering paths;
With glimpses of dim windows and grey walls
Just caught at here and there amongst the green
Of flowering shrubs and sweet limeâavenues.
An old house standing nearâa parsonageâhouseâ
With broad thatched roof and overhanging eaves,
Oâer run with banksia roses,âa low house,
With ivied windows and a latticed porch,
Shut in a tiny Paradise, all sweet
With hum of bees and scent of mignonette.
We lay our lazy length upon the grass
In that same Paradise, my friend and I.
And, as we lay, we talked of college daysâ
Wild, racing, hunting, steepleâchasing days;
Of river reaches, fishingâgrounds, and weirs,
Bats, gloves, debates, and inâhumanities:
And then of boonâcompanions of those days,
How lost and scattered, married, changed, and dead;
Until he flung his arm across his face,
And feigned to slumber.
He was changed, my friend;
Not like the manâthe leader of his setâ
The favourite of the collegeâthat I knew.
And more than time had changed him. He had been
âA little wild,â the Lady Alice said;
âA little gay, as all young men will be
At first, before they settle down to lifeâ
While they have money, health, and no restraint,
Nor any work to do.â Ah, yes! But this
Was mystery unexplainedâthat he was sad
And still and thoughtful, like an aged man;
And scarcely thirty. With a winsome flash,
The old bright heart would shine out here and there;
But aye to be oâer shadowed and hushed down,
As he had hushed it now.
His dog lay near,
With long, sharp muzzle resting on his paws,
And wistful eyes, half shut,âbut watching him;
A deerhound of illustrious race, all grey
And grizzled, with soft, wrinkled, velvet ears;
A gaunt, gigantic, wolfishâlooking brute,
And worth his weight in gold.
âThere, there,â said he,
And raised him on his elbow, âyou have looked
Enough at me; now look at some one else.â
âYou could not see him, surely, with your arm
Across your face?â
âNo, but I felt his eyes;
They are such sharp, wise eyesâpersistent eyesâ
Perpetually reproachful. Look at them;
Had ever dog such eyes?â
âOh yes,â I thought;
But, wondering, turned my talk upon his breed.
And was he of the famed Glengarry stock?
And in what season was he entered? Where,
Pray, did he pick him up?
He moved himself
At that last question, with a little writhe
Of sudden pain or restlessness; and sighed.
And then he slowly rose, pushed back the hair
From his broad brows; and, whistling softly, said,
âCome here, old dog, and we will tell him. Come.â
âOn such a day, and such a time, as this,
Old Tom and I were stalking on the hills,
Near seven years ago. Bad luck was ours;
For we had searched up corrie, glen, and burn,
From earliest daybreakâwading to the waist
Peatârift and purple heatherâall in vain!
We struck a track nigh every hour, to lose
A noble quarry by ignoble chanceâ
The crowing of a grouseâcock, or the flight
Of startled mallards from a reedy pool,
Or subtle, hairâs breadth veering of the wind.
And now âtwas waning sunsetârosy soft
On far grey peaks, and the green valley spread
Beneath us. We had climbed a ridge, and lay
Debating in low whispers of our plans
For night and morning. Golden eagles sailed
Above our heads; the wild ducks swam about
Amid the reeds and rushes of the pools;
A lonely heron stood on one long leg
In shallow water, watching for a meal;
And there, to windward, couching in the grass
That fringed the blue edge of a sleeping lochâ
Waiting for dusk to feed and drinkâthere lay
A herd of deer.
âAnd as we looked and planned,
A mountain storm of sweeping mist and rain
Came down upon us. It passed by, and left
The burnies swollen that we had to cross;
And left us barely light enough to see
The broad, black, branching antlers, clustering still
Amid the long grass in the valley.
ââSir,â
Said Tom, âthere is a shealing down below,
To leeward. We might bivouac there toânight,
And come again at dawn.â
âAnd so we crept
Adown the glen, and stumbled in the dark
Against the doorway of the keeperâs home,
And over two big deerhoundsâancestors
Of this our old companion. There was light
And warmth, a welcome and a heather bed,
At Colinâs cottage; with a meal of eggs
And fresh trout, broiled by dainty little hands,
And sweetest milk and oatcake. There were songs
And Gaelic legends, and long talk of deerâ
Mixt with a sweet, low laughter, and the whir
Of spinningâwheel.
âThe dogs lay at her feetâ
The feet of Colinâs daughterâwith their soft
Dark velvet ears pricked up for every sound
And movement that she made. Right royal brutes,
Whereon I gazed with envy.
ââWhat,â I asked,
âWould Colin take for these?â
ââEh, sir,â said he,
And shook his head, âI cannot sell the dogs.
Theyâre priceless, they, andâJeanieâs favourites.
But thereâs a litter in the shedâfive pups,
As like as peas to this one. You may choose
Amongst them, sirâtake any that you like.
Get us the lantern, Jeanie. You shall show
The gentleman.â
âAh, she was fair, that girl!
Not like the other lassiesâcottage folk;
For there was subtle trace of gentle blood
Through all her beauty and in all her ways.
(The motherâs race was âpoor and proud,â they said).
Ay, she was fair, my darling! with her shy,
Brown, innocent face and delicateâshapen limbs.
She had the tenderest mouth you ever saw,
And grey, dark eyes, and broad, straightâpencillâd brows;
Dark hair, sunâdappled with a sheeny gold;
Dark chestnut braids that knotted up the light,
As soft as satin. You could scarcely hear
Her step, or hear the rustling of her gown,
Or the soft hovering motion of her hands
At household work. She seemed to bring a spell
Of tender calm and silence where she came.
You felt her presenceâand not by its stir,
But by its restfulness. She was a sight
To be rememberedâstanding in the straw;
A sleepy pup softâcradled in her arms
Like any Christian baby; standing still,
The while I handled his ungainly limbs.
And Colin blustered of the sportâof hounds,
Roe ptarmigan, and trout, and ducal deerâ
Neâer lifting up that sweet, unconscious face,
To see why I was silent. Oh, I would
You could have seen her then. She was so fair,
And oh, so young!âscarce seventeen at mostâ
So ignorant and so young!
âTell them, my friendâ
Your flockâthe restlessâheartedâthey who scorn
The ordered fashion fitted to our race,
And scoff at laws they may not understandâ
Tell them that they are fools. They cannot mate
With other than their kind, but woe will come
In some shapeâmostly shame, but always grief
And disappointment. Ah, my love! my love!
But she was different from the common sort;
A peasant, ignorant, simple, undefiled;
The child of rugged peasantâparents, taught
In all their thoughts and ways; yet with that touch
Of tender grace about her, softening all
The rougher evidence of her lowly stateâ
That undefined, unconscious dignityâ
That delicate instinct for the reading right
The riddles of less simple minds than hersâ
That sharper, finer, subtler sense of lifeâ
That something which does not possess a name,
Which made her beauty beautiful to meâ
The longâlost legacy of forgotten knights.
âI chose amongst the five fat creeping things
This rare old dog. And Jeanie promised kind
And gentle nurture for its infant days;
And promised she would keep it till I came
Another year. And so we went to rest.
And in the morning, ere the sun was up,
We left our rifles, and went out to run
The browsing redâdeer with old Colinâs hounds.
Through glen and bog, through brawling mountain streams,
Grey, lichened boulders, furze, and juniper,
And purple wilderness of moor, we toiled,
Ere yet the distant snowâpeak was alight.
We chased a hart to water; saw him stand
At bay, with sweeping antlers, in the burn.
His large, wild, wistful eyes despairingly
Turned to the deeper eddies; and we saw
The choking struggle and the bitter end,
And cut his gallant throat upon the grass,
And left him. Then we followed a fresh trackâ
A dozen tracksâand hunted till the noon;
Shot cormorants and wild cats in the cliffs,
And snipe and blackcock on the ferny hills;
And set our floating nightâlines at the loch;â
And then came back to Jeanie.
âWell, you know
What follows such commencement:âhow I found
The woods and corries round about her home
Fruitful of roe and redâdeer; how I found
The grouse lay thickest on adjacent moors;
Discovered ptarmigan on rocky peaks,
And rare small game on birchâbesprinkled hills,
Oâershadowing that rude shealing; how the pools
Were full of wildâfowl, and the loch of trout;
How vermin harboured in the underwood,
And rocks, and reedy marshes; how I found
The sport aye best in this charmed neighbourhood.
And then I eâen must wander to the door,
To leave a bird for Colin, or to ask
A lodging for some stormy night, or see
How fared my infant deerhound.
âAnd I saw
The creeping dawn unfolding; saw the doubt,
And faith, and longing swaying her sweet heart;
And every flow just distancing the ebb.
I saw her try to bar the golden gates
Whence love demanded egress,âcalm her eyes,
And still the tender, sensitive, tellâtale lips,
And steal away to corners; saw her face
Grow graver and more wistful, day by day;
And felt the gradual strengthening of my hold.
I did not stay to think of itâto ask
What I was doing!
âIn the early time,
She used to slip away to household work
When I was there, and would not talk to me;
But when I came not, she would climb the glen
In secret, and look out, with shaded brow,
Across the valley. Ay, I caught her onceâ
Like some young helpless doe, amongst the fernâ
I caught her, and I kissed her mouth and eyes;
And with those kisses signed and sealed our fate
For evermore. Then came our happy daysâ
The bright, brief, shining days without a cloud!
In ferny hollows and deep, rustling woods,
That shut us in and shut out all the worldâ
The far, forgotten worldâwe met, and kissed,
And parted, silent, in the balmy dusk.
We haunted still roeâcoverts, hand in hand,
And murmured, under our breath, of love and faith,
And swore great oaths for one of us to keep.
We sat for hours, with sealÃ¨d lips, and heard
The sweet wind whispering as it passed us byâ
And heard our own heartsâ music in the hush.
Ah, blessed days! ah, happy, innocent days!â
I would I had them back.
âThen came the Duke,
And Lady Alice, with her worldly grace
And artificial beautyâwith the gleam
Of jewels, and the dainty shine of silk,
And perfumed softness of white lace and lawn;
With all the glamour of her courtly ways,
Her talk of art and fashion, and the world
We both belonged to. Ah, she hardened me!
I lost the sweetness of the heathery moors
And hills and quiet woodlands, in that scent
Of London clubs and royal drawingârooms;
I lost the tender chivalry of my love,
The keen sense of its sacredness, the clear
Perception of mine honour, by degrees,
Brought face to face with customs of my kind.
I was no more a âman;â nor she, my love,
A delicate lily of womanhoodâah, no!
I was the heir of an illustrious house,
And she a simple homespun cottageâgirl.
âAnd now I stole at rarer intervals
To those dim trysting woods; and when I came
I brought my cunning worldly wisdomâtalked
Of empty forms and marriages in heavenâ
To stain that simple soul, God pardon me!
And she would shiver in the stillness, scared
And shocked, with her pathetic eyesâaye proof
Against the fatal, false philosophy.
But my will was the strongest, and my love
The weakest; and she knew it.
âWell, well, well,
I need not talk of that. There came the day
Of our last parting in the ferny glenâ
A bitter parting, parting from my life,
Its light and peace for ever! And I turned
To balls and billiards, politics and wine;
Was wooed by Lady Alice, and half won;
And passed a feverous winter in the world.
Ah, do not frown! You do not understand.
You never knew that hopeless thirst for peaceâ
That gnawing hunger, gnawing at your life;
The passion, born too late! I tell you, friend,
The ruth, and love, and longing for my child,
It broke my heart at last.
âIn the hot days
Of August, I went back; I went alone.
And on old garrulous Margeryârelict she
Of some departed seneschalâI rained
My eager questions. âHad the poaching been
As ruinous and as audacious as of old?
Were the dogs well? and had she felt the heat?
AndâI supposed the keeper, Colin, still
Was somewhere on the place?â
ââNay, sir,â said she,
âBut he has left the neighbourhood. He neâer
Has held his head up since he lost his child,
Poor soul, a month ago.â
âI heardâI heard!
His childâhe had but oneâmy little one,
Whom I had meant to marry in a week!
ââAh, sir, she turned out badly after all,
The girl we thought a pattern for all girls.
We know not how it happened, for she named
No names. And, sir, it preyed upon her mind,
And weakened it; and she forgot us all,
And seemed as one aye walking in her sleep
She noticed no oneâno one but the dog,
A young deerhound that followed her about;
Though him she hugged and kissed in a strange way
When none was by. And Colin, he was hard
Upon the girl; and when she sat so still,
And pale and passive, while he raved and stormed,
Looking beyond him, as it were, he grew
The harder and more harsh. He did not know
That she was not herself. Men are so blind!
But when he saw her floating in the loch,
The moonlight on her face, and her long hair
All tangled in the rushes; saw the hound
Whining and crying, tugging at her plaidâ
Ah, sir, it was a deathâstroke!â
âThis was all.
This was the end of her sweet lifeâthe end
Of all worth having of mine own! At night
I crept across the moors to find her grave,
And kiss the wet earth covering itâand found
The deerhound lying there asleep. Ay me!
It was the bitterest darkness,ânevermore
To break out into dawn and day again!
âAnd Lady Alice shakes her dainty head,
Lifts her arch eyebrows, smiles, and whispers, â â Once
He was a little wild!ââ
With that he laughed;
Then suddenly flung his face upon the grass,
Crying, âLeave me for a littleâlet me be!â
And in the dusky stillness hugged his woe,
And wept away his passion by himself.
WE have heard many sermons, you and I,
And many more may hear,
When sitting quiet in cathedral nave,
With folded palms and faces meek and grave;â
But few like this one, dear.
We ofttimes watch together âfore the veil,
With reverent, gleaming eyes,
While priestly hands are busy with the folds,â
And pant to see the holy place, which holds
Lifeâs dreadest mysteries.
We watch weak, foolish fingers straying oâer
The broidered boss, to grasp
Vaguely at some small end of thread, and twist
And shake the glorious pattern into mist,
And leave us nought to clasp.
We watch, with eyes dilated, some strong hand
Of nerve and muscle, trace
The grand, faint outlines, erewhile undefined
To our slow earthâenfolded sense, and find
The great designâthe shadow from behindâ
Dawning before our face.
But seldom do we see, dear, you and I,
The pattern melt in light,
And all the shine flow out on us, uncheckâdâ
With eyes of soul and not of intellectâ
As we did see that night.
It was a summerânightâthe sun was low,
But overlaid the sea,
And made goldâcrystals of the wet seaâsand,
And drew our shadows short upon the strand
That stretched out shallowly.
It was a Sunday nightâfar off we heard
The solemn vesperâchime
From some grey windâswept steeple by the shore,
Chanting âFor evâerâmore! for evâerâmore!â
While the deep sea beat time.
We wandered far that night, dear, you and I,
We wandered out of reach,â
Until the golden distances grew grey,
And narrowed in the glory, as it lay
âMid horizon and beach.
We wandered far along the lonely waste,
Where seldom foot had trod;
The world behind us dared not to intrudeâ
The summer silence and the solitude
Were only filled with God.
We sat down on the sand there, you and I,
We sat down awed and dumb,
And watched the fiery circle fall and fall
Through solemn folds of purple, and the small
Soft ripples go and come.
There was not wind enough to stir the reeds
Around us, nor to curl
The sheeny, dimpled surface of the deep;
The waters murmured low, as half in sleep,
With measured swish and swirl.
Two seaâbirds came and dabbled in the pools,
And cried their plaintive cry,
As their strong wings swept oâer us as we sat
(No profanation of the stillness that,
But added sanctity).
They flecked the crimson shallows with black streaks,
Lowâwheeling to and fro,
Crying their bold, sweet cry, as knowing well
It was a place where God, not man, did dwellâ
A father, not a foe.
Ah, we hear many sermons, you and Iâ
The poor words fall and drown;
But this, whose speech was silence, this has stirred
The stream of years,âand aye it will be heard
As when that sun went down!

div.head: THE LAST BATTLE OF THE CID.

lg.l: LOW he lay upon his dying couch, the knight without a stain,
The unconquered Cid CampeadÃ³r, the bright breastplate of Spain,
The incarnate honour of Castille, of Aragon and Navarre,
Very crown of Spanish chivalry, Rodrigo of Bivar!
Sick he lay, and grieved in spirit, for that Paynim dogs should dare
Camp around his knightly citadel, Valencia the fair!
For that he no more should face them, in his beauteous armour dight,
To whom God and Santiago aye gave victory in the fight.
Faintly rising oâer the ramparts came the murmur of the siege,
And he could but pray for Christendom, his country and his liege;
For his wellâbelovÃ¨d city, graniteâgirdled, pennonâstarred,
And the royal wealth of treasure that its stately portals barred.
âSantiago, at whose altar I did watch mine armour bright,
And was girt with golden spur and brand, a consecrated knight!â
Santiago, by my vow redeemed at Compostelaâs shrine,
Let the Paynim lifeâblood only touch these blessed walls of mine!
âSantiago, warrior saintly, who with Don Fernandoâs host
Stormed and won the gates of Coimbra, guard my fortress on the coast!
Keep the holy leperâs blessing, though the snow is on my hair;â
Strike the baseâborn unbelievers!âsave Valencia the fair!â
Lo, a sudden cloud of glory filled his chamber as he prayed!
Lo, San Pedro stood beside him, all in shining robes arrayed!
âFor thy love, Rodrigo Diaz, to CardeÃ±aâs house,â said he,
âI have offered intercessions, and the Lord hath answered me.
âThou must die, O wellâbeloved!âthirty days, and thou must die!
Yet in death shall Santiago grant thee still a victory.
Thou shalt ride forth to the battleâSantiago shall be thereâ
For the Faith and Don Alfonso and Valencia the fair.â
Silence reigned within the chamber; none stood near the heroâs bed;
All that dazzling flood of glory slowly, softly vanishÃ¨d.
He could only hear the murmur from the ramparts rise and fall;
He could only see the crossâbars stretching dimly on the wall.
In San Pedroâs chapel lay the Cid, his eyes with rapture dim,
And proclaimed the wondrous favour that the Lord had granted him.
Then he parted from his vassals, and went humbly to confess;
And the warriorâbishop clothed his soul in its baptismal dress.
âTwas the holy day of Pentecost that saw Ruy Diaz dieâ
Evermore the spotless mirror of Castillian chivalry!
They, in whom his will was shrinÃ¨d, Alvar Fanez and his knights,
Stood to watch the hero vanquished who had won a thousand fights.
DoÃ±a Ximena, the faithful, with her tears bedewed his feet,
And anointed all his body with pure incense, rich and sweet.
Then in silence and in sorrow the twelve days of waiting fled;
And the warders on the ramparts dared not whisper, âHe is dead.â
In the midnight, dark and quiet, fell the torchesâ lurid glare
On the palaces and portals of Valencia the fair;
And a solemn, slow procession, mounted all in royal state,
Like the spectre of an army, passed beneath the city gate.
In the van was borne the ensign, known and dreaded far and wide,
With four hundred noblest knights ranged proudly by its side.
Toward Castille and CardeÃ±a were those haughty faces set,â
And that banner never more did crown Valenciaâs parapet.
Then came mules, with treasure laden, stepping softly on before,
Compassed round with knights in armourâto the full four hundred more.
Then a band of belted nobles, stern and silent; and amid
Their levelled lances, he of Bivarâthe CampeadÃ³râ the Cid.
On his milkâwhite steed, Babieca, whom none else did eâer bestride,
Clad in all his princely trappings, did the lifeless warrior ride;
Girt with helm and spur and blazoned shield, and grasping in his hand
The bright crosslet of Tizona, his thriceâconsecrated brand.
Geronymo and Gil Diaz held the slackened bridleâreinâ
His true bishop and true vassalâas they moved on to the plain;
And Ximena and her maidens, âmid the torchlight weird and dim,
With six hundred knights in harness, followed slowly after him.
In the solemn hush and darkness, with no joyful clarionâcry,
And no clash and clank of weapons, riding all so silently;â
Thus they passed out from the city eâer the summer morning broke,
And were found arrayed for battle when the infidels awoke.
Great and mighty was the Moorish host, by thirty monarchs led,
But a greater was the army with Rodrigo at the head;
For behold! came Santiago to the bloody battleâplainâ
Santiago, with a hundred thousand warriors in his train.
Each in robe of shining whiteness, with a red cross on his breast,â
Each with fiery sword uplifted or with golden lance at rest;
Santiago, saintly leader, on a charger white as snowâ
Sent to aid the Cid CampeadÃ³r in vanquishing the foe.
All the Paynims looked amazÃ¨d on the dreadful beauteous sight.
As the tender light of morning softly crept out from the night;
Then they harnessed them in silence, sternly grasping shield and spear,
And pressed on in serried column, full of wonder, full of fear.
There was one loud shock of battle, then they wildly turned to flee,
And the Cid and Santiago swept their hosts into the sea.
Twenty kings and twenty armies in that bloody fight were slain,
And were left, with upturned faces, stiff and stark upon the plain.
Fair and shining came the daylight, all in liquid summer sheenâ
But no more was Santiago, or his whiteârobed warriors, seen;
Only one small train of nobles, riding on, with stately pace,
To San Pedro de CardeÃ±a and the great Cidâs restingâplace.
By the altar in the chapel, where the monarchâs throne doth stand,
Sat the dead Cid, robed in purple, with his good sword in his hand.
And again the Moorish ensign fluttered proudly in the air,
Lifted high above the ramparts of Valencia the fair.
O FOR wings! that I might soar
A little way above the floor,
A little way beyond the roarâ
A little nearer to the sky!
To the blue hills, lifted high
Out of all our misery.
Where alone is heard the lark,
Warbling in the infinite arc
From the dawning to the dark;
Where the callow eaglets wink
On the bare and breezy brink,
And slow pinions rise and sink.
Where the dim white breakers beat
Under cloudâdrifts at our feet,
Singing, singing, low and sweet;
Where we see the glimmering bay
Greyly melting far away,
On the confines of the day;
Where the green larchâfringes sweep
Rocky defiles, still and steep;
Where the tender lichens creep;
Where the gentianâblossoms blow,
Set in crystal stars of snow;
Where the downward torrents flow
To the plains and yellow leas,
Glancing, twinkling through the treesâ
Pure, as from celestial seas.
Where the face of heaven has smiled
Aye on freedom, sweet and wild,
Aye on beauty undefiled.
Where no sound of human speech,
And no human passions, reach;
Where the angels sit and teach.
Where no troublous foot has trod;
Where is impressed on the sod
Only hand and heart of God!
âFRIEND,â quoth Lord Nevil, âthou art young
To face the world, and thou art blind
To subtle ways of womankind;
The meshes thou wilt fall among.
âTake an old married manâs advice;
Use the experience I have earned;
Watch well where women are concerned,â
Theyâre not all birds of paradise!
âBe circumspect, or thou mayst fall;
Abjure a blind faithânay, trust noneâ
Till thou hast chosen, proven one;
Then trust her trulyâtrust in all.
âKeep a calm brain and quiet eye,
And watch. The doll of powder and paint,
The flirt, the artificial saint,
The loud manâwoman pass them by.
âThe innocent one, who craves thy cares
To shield her from lifeâs fret and fray;
Lad, watch herâmaybe sheâll betray
Some doubtful knowledge, unawares.
âThe pensive one, who droops and sighsâ
Wait till her dreaming comes to test;
Be gentle, yet be wary, lest
âTis but a graceful grey disguise.
âThe worldâwise husbandâhunterâshe
Who knows no love but love of gold,
And lands and titlesâempty, cold,â
Pity her, lad, and let her be.
âAnd the rich heiressâlet her pass.
Belike sheâs stupid, drugged with wealth,
And just enjoys her life and health
As some fat cow in clover grass.
âOr insolent with prosperity,
Unsharpened, shallow, unrefined;â
And thou art poor, and thou wilt mind
That proud blood cometh down to thee.
âThe gushing gossipâshe who rains
Incessant chatter in thine ears;â
She may be worth thy keenest fears,
She may be simply lacking brains,
âAnd lacking grace and modesty.
She will make mischief, at the best;
She may be wily, like the rest;
Keep thy tongue still when she is by.
âThey that would master thee, if they could,
In brain and muscleâflaring lightsâ
The clamorous for false womanâs rights;â
Snub them, my friendâit does them goodâ
âAnd do not think of them for wives.
Fit mates for such seem somewhat rare;
But when two odd ones make a pair,
They spoil at least four precious lives.
âBut shouldst thou chance to meet a girl
With brave, bright eyes, that front thee straight,
A kindly tongue that does not prate,
And quiet lips that cannot curl;
âWith fine sense, quick to understand,
With dignity that is not cold,
Sweet, sunny mirth that is not bold,
A ready ear, a willing hand;
âOne skilled in household arts, and skilled
In little courteous, graceful ways,
That make no show and win no praiseâ
Wherewith discordant jars are stilled:
âOne who will never touch a sore;
One who sheds sunshine round about,
And draws lifeâs hidden comfort out;
One whom the boys and babes adore:
âOne with an intellect to reach
The highest range that thou canst rise;
Who will aye help thee, womanâwise,
And yet not set herself to teach:
âOne of whom women love to speak,
In honest kindness, and whose name
Men let alone; whose chiefest fame
Lies hidden where men may not seek;â
âFriend, woo her, as a good knight can,
And win her. Lay thou at her feet
Faith, love, and honour, true and sweet;
And count thyself a happy man.â
O SWEET darkness, still, and calm, and lonely!
Spread thy downy pinions round about.
Spare me from thy hidden riches only
One dreamâface; blot all the others out.
Bring him now, for thou hast power to free him,
From that ugly garb he wears by day;
Bring him nowâmy darling!âlet me see him
Ere the tender kindness pass away.
O sweet nightâwinds, wandering in the larches!
Sigh, and croon, and whisper as you creep;
Sing my songs through green cathedral arches,
While the weary workers are asleep.
Snarl and fret not of the grief and passion;
Sing in minor cadence, sweet and low;
Sing of peace and rest, in soft windâfashionâ
Of the love and faith I used to know!

div.head: THE MIDNIGHT MASS.
An Incident of the French Revolution.

lg.l: THE light lay trembling in a silver bar
Along the western borders of the sky;
From out the shadowy dome a little star
Stole forth to keep its patient watch on high;
And night came down, with solemn, soft embrace,
On storied Brittany.
Another night lay over all the landâ
The dark of hell, and lurid with its fire.
She heard the roar of fiends; she saw the brand
Flung red and hissing over roof and spire;
She saw her golden spurs and reapingâhooks
Tossed on the funeral pyre.
She stood in calm defiance, while the flood
Swept over her;âwhile everywhere was seen
Her dim, majestic cities drenched in blood;
Ashes and smoke where templeâwalls had been;
And high on woodland knoll and marketâplace,
The ghastly guillotine.
âTwas hard to tear her peasantâsouls apart
From priest and liege, and clinging faith of old;
âTwas hard to bend the strong and simple heart
By fear of torture or by love of gold:
For naught those gory hands could offer them
Might consciences be sold.
âNo tower or belfry shall be left to stand,â
Saint AndrÃ© swore, and waved his cap of red;
âYou shall have naught in all this cursÃ¨d land
For sign of your superstition,âit is dead!â
A peasant heard, and raised his eyes to heaven;â
âYouâll leave the stars,â he said.
True were the priests and people, each to each,
And all alike to their unlettered creed;
No violent force of sophistry could reach
Their roughâhewn faith in bitter time of need.
They died with deaf ears and dumb mouths; and theirs
Was martyrdom indeed!
Nightâmidnightâlay beneath her silver lamps;
Her deep sleep broken by the fitful glare
Of bivouac fires in noisy village camps,
And hoarse shouts mellowed through the listening air;
Save only where the seaâwaves washed the coastâ
âTwas still and quiet there:
The heave and swell, and sudden, plunging dash
Against the low rocks lying in their reach;
The hissing shingle, and the sweet, free plash
Of longâdrawn breakers on the open beach;
And now and then, in momentary pause,
The curlewâs mournful screech:
The soft, low gurgle in the hollowed track
Through reef and boulder; and the rippling fall
Of idle wandering waters, swirling back
From secret tryst in Naiadsâ rocky hall;â
Only these soundsâsave that deep monotone
Which held and hushed them all.
Only these sounds? Was nothing to be heard
But voice of breaker as it rose and fell,
The kelpieâs song, the wailing of a bird?
Ay, far and faint amid the restless swell,
One other voice stole whispering through the airâ
The chime of a silver bell.
It came from dim midâocean, wild and free,
To listening ears, in silence of the night;
And watchful eyes saw, out upon the sea
And âneath the stars, a little twinkling lightâ
Now lost behind a waving mountainâtop,
Now shining clear and bright.
Softly the fishersâ boats began to glide
From shadowy rock and sheltered cave and creek;
Bronzed men and gentle maidens, side by side,
Dipped muffled oars; no womanâhand was weak.
All eyes turned, wistful, to the beaconâlamp;
But no one dared to speak.
The scattered specks, with each its little crowd,
Drew near, converging on the distant bark;
The sweet bell rang out louder and more loud,
The light shone bright and brighter in the dark:
And soon a hundred lips burst forth in praiseâ
For all had reachâd the ark.
There was the priest, with whom they came to sup,
Whiteâhairâd and holy, by his humble board;
There, amid light and darkness lifted up,
The blessed rood, by simple eyes adored.
Each head was bowed, each pious knee was bent
In presence of the Lord.
Ah! âtwas a grand cathedral where they knelt!
Grand was the organâmusicâvast the crypt
Wherein its wild, mysterious echoes dwelt;
And fresh and pure the incense, as it slippâd
Down shining floor and down wide altarâsteps,
With frosted silver tippâd.
Grand was the darkenâd aisles and solemn naveâ
The domÃ¨d roof, magnificently highâ
The airy walls and mighty architraveâ
The sweet starâtapers that could never die!
And grander still its purity of peace,
Its untouched sanctity.
The worn and weary ones came there, to search
For rest and hope in holy Eucharist;
Thereâin the splendour of that solemn churchâ
They, priest and people, communed with the Christ;
Thusâwith all other temples overthrownâ
They kept his sacred tryst.
With calm, grave eyes and evenâpulsing breath,
They dippâd their still oars in the darkenâd space.
Strong now the hands fast rowing back to death!â
And strong the simple hearts, new clothed in graceâ
The hushâd and quiet soulsâere long to meet
Their Saviour face to face.
AY, many and many a yearâs gone by,
Since the dawn of that day in spring,
When we met in the pineâwoods, Harry and I,
And he gave me this golden ring.
I had lovers in plenty, of high degree,
Who wooed in my fatherâs hall;
But none were so noble and brave as he,
Though he was the scornâd of all.
On the soft, green grass, where the shadows lay,
All fleckâd with the sun and dew,
With a ring and a kiss did we seal, that day,
Our vow to be leal and true.
âTwas a lifeâlong vow;âbut they did not knowâ
And they thought not of love or pain;â
We met just once in the sleet and snowâ
We were never to meet again!
He was sent away oâer the blank, wide sea,
And I, with my hopes and fears,
Had never a message to comfort me
For over a score of years.
They laughâd at my heart, they paraded my hand,
But I answerâd them, cold and grimâ
âIf Harry neâer comes to his native land,
They shall only belong to him.â
At last came a tale from the battleâfield;â
And they were not scornful now.
The sentence of exile might be repealedâ
They would honour our plighted vow!
They told how my Harry, like olden knights,
Had fought for his land and Queen;
Fought hard and well on the Alma heights,
Where the deadliest strife was seen.
They told how he fell in the fire and smoke,
And they gave me his things to keep;
They wonderâd why I never cried or spoke,â
But it was too late to weep.
O TAKE away your dried and painted garlands!
The snowâclothâs fallen from each quickenâd brow,
The stoneâs rolled off the sepulchre of winter,
And risen leaves and flowers are wanted now.
Send out the little ones, that they may gather
With their pure hands the firstlings of the birth,â
Greenâgolden tufts and delicate halfâblown blossoms,
Sweet with the fragrance of the Easter earth;
Great primrose bunches, with soft, damp moss clinging
To their brown fibres, nursed in hazel roots;
And violets from the shady banks and copses,
And woodâanemones, and white hawthorn shoots;
And tender curling fronds of fern, and grasses
And crumpled leaves from brink of babbling rills,
With cottageâgarden treasuresâpale narcissi
And lilac plumes and yellow daffodils.
Open the doors, and let the Easter sunshine
Flow warmly in and out, in amber waves,
And let the perfume floating round our altar
Meet the new perfume from the outer graves.
And let the Easter âAlleluia!â mingle
With the sweet silver rainânotes of the lark;
Let us all sing together!âLent is over,
Captivity and winter, death and dark.
âON board the Petrel, in St. Luciaâs bay,
Of yellow feverâaged twentyânine.â
âWho did you say, my lady?â drawled the Earl.
âThe dukeâwhat duke?â
âI did not speak of dukes,â
Replied the Countess slowly, white and grim,
Pressing the rustling sheet between her palms,
The while her diamonds heaved upon her breast,
And sank and heaved, and glitterâd like her eyesâ
Hungry, pathetic eyes,âââTis only Dick,
Only a sailorâlad I used to know.â
âHumph! A West Indian friend?â he softly sneerâd,
And bowâd and gave his arm. âThe carriage waitsâ
My lady loses time.â
Then passâd they out,
Through silky servants,âhe, the great Earl, stark
In plume and crest and linked mediÃ¦val steel,
The Countess en bergÃ¨re, in white and red,
With roses, diamond dewâdropped, in her hat
And in her queenly bosom;âpassâd they out,
And, through clear gaslight and the avenue
Of silent ChampsâElysÃ©es, to the fÃªte.
Her restless eyes were blind to all the blaze
And motley splendour of the throngâd saloons;
The flowers, the cool cascades, the magic wand
Of Strauss, the vineâdraped balustrades, the gaze
Of wistful admiration meeting hers
At every step. The Empress smiled and bowâd,
The Emperor praised the beauty and the taste
Of her mockârustic costume, princes begged
Her fair hand for the dance, and her grim lord
Scowlâd, wrathful, on her when she passâd him by.
She cared for none,âshe lookâd beyond them all.
She saw another nightâa hot, bright nightâ
A night of years agoâdanced out in joy
âNeath the low roofâtree of a planterâs house
In fair Antiguaâs bosom;âsaw the stars,
Large, liquid, golden, swimming in the blue,
Shining through open doors and jalousies,
And the green sparkles of the fireâflies, thick
About the forest, fringing all the dark;
The crimson creepers swaying in the air
From white verandah pillarsâswaying soft;
The small nest of a hummingâbird; the stems,
Brownâringâd, of feathery palmâtrees,âplaintains bowâd
With broad, thick leaves, and clustering fruit, and seeds
In scarlet vesselsâorangeâgroves, whiteâflowerâd
And sweet, with hanging balls of green and goldâ
All vaguely outlined in the mellow night.
And nearer still a brave, brown English face,
Bent low, with clear grey eyes and faithful lips
That whisperâd, âReine, I love you,â meeting hers.
The drowsy sound of laughter and light feet
Behind them she could hearâbut the quick throb
Of poor Dickâs English heart upon her breast
She felt to suffocation. âReine, my sweet,
I love youâReine, I love you; kiss me, child.â
And her soft hands strayâd softly round his neck,
And softer still she kissâd him.
Then she saw
A morning, hot and stormyâsaw the Earl,
Drunk with her wondrous beauty, standing there
Where Dick had stood. She saw his cultured ways,
His highâbred, stately courtesy and grace;
She heard his subtle flatteries, his tales
Of the great world, of court and city life,
With gaping ears and speculating brain.
The voice of the archâtempter, low and soft,
Spoke in his polished accents, âReine, âtis sin,
âTis sin and shame, that such a face as yours
Should waste its sweetness in these heathen isles.
Thereâs not a fairer face in Europe, Reine;
âTis worth a coronet. Come back with me
As a great earlâs wife; in his diamonds dressâd,
You would have homage like a crownÃ¨d queen.â
She shudderâd now,âhis diamonds gallâd her worse
Than felonâs chains.
Anon she saw a bayâ
Blue, limpid water, fringed with dipping palms,
A green rockâgateway opening on the sea,
Green caneâfields stretching upward, woods and hills
Lying entangled in the summer clouds;
An English ship at anchorâburning noonâ
A thin, brown, feverâd face, with hungry eyes
Roaming from side to side, in dumb appeal,
Which none could understand,âand dying lips
Muttering to vacant air and heedless ears,
âI love you, Reine, I love you!â
âO my loveâ
O Dickâmy Dickâwould I could sleep with thee
In thy last happy sleep among the palms,
With my dead hands claspâd tight about thy neck!
O Dick, I did not mean itâdid not thinkâ
And now my heart is broken!
âTake me home.
The rooms are hot, my lord, and I am faintâ
The music makes me giddy. Take me home!â
A WAVEâWORN boulder, with green seaâmoss wrapping
A silken mantle oâer its jagged sides;
And silvery, seething waters softly lapping
Through gulfs and channels hollowâd by the tides:
A limeâcliff overhead, oâerhanging grimly,
A dash of sunlight on its breast of snow;
The white line of the breakers, stretching dimly
Along the narrow seaâbeach down below:
The grey waste of the waters, with one slender,
Glimmering, golden ripple far away;
The haze of summer twilight, sweet and tender,
Veiling the fair face of the dying day:
The measured plash of surf upon the shingle,
The ceaseless gurgle through the rocks and stones;
No sound of struggling human life, to mingle
With those mysterious and eternal tones!
No soundâno sound,âa hungry seaâmew only
Breaking the stillness with her little cry;
And the low whisper, when âtis all so lonely,
Of soft south breezes as they wander by:â
I see it all; sweet dreams of it are thronging
In full floods back upon my weary brain;
Toânight, in my dark chamber, the old longing
Almost fulfils its very self again.
The dying sunbeams, on the far waves glinting,
Come like warm kisses to my lips and brow,
Soothing my spiritâall its grey thoughts tinting
With tender shades of golden colour now.
Alone and still, I sit, and think, and listen,
Looking out westward oâer the darkening sea;
My seat the boulder, where the sprayâdrops glisten;
The tall, white cliffs my regal canopy.
And, as I sit, the fretting cares and sorrows,
Weighing so heavy when the work is done,
The gloomy yesterdays and dim toâmorrows,
They slip away and vanish one by one,â
Slip backward to the world that lies behind me,
Every by sinful footsteps overtrod;
And in this unstainâd world leave nought to bind me,
This sweet world, fillÃ¨d with the peace of God!
ALL the wild waves rockâd in shadow,
And the world was dim and grey,
Dark and silent, hushâd and breathless,
Waiting calmly for the day.
And the golden light came stealing
Oâer the mountainâtops at lastâ
Flooding vale and wood and upland,â
It was morningânight was past.
There they layâthe silvery waters,
Fruitful forests, glade and lawn;â
All in beauty, newâcreated
By the angel of the dawn.
So my spirit slept in twilight;â
All was quiet, grey, and still,
Till the dawn of Love came stealing,
Over Hopeâs snowâcrested hill.
Then the dim world woke in glory,
And the irisâdyes grew bright
On the waves and woods and valleys,
In a morning flood of light.
Ah! the vineyards and the gardens!â
Ah! the treasures, rich and rare,
Full of endless life and beauty,
Which that dawn created there!
ONE winter eve, at twilight, when the sound
Of sorrowful winds scarce troubled Natureâs rest,
As she lay sleeping, with her hair unbound,
Holding her grey robe to her shivering breast,
I enterâd through a lowâarchâd oaken door,
Circled with curious sculpture; and I crept
With slow, hushâd footsteps, oâer the shadowâd floor,
Where organ notes in sudden silence slept;
Far down the aisle, where darkness seemâd to brood
With such wideâspreading wings, and where the sigh
Of murmurâd prayer scarce came,âuntil I stood
In the deep stillness of the Baptistry.
There, in the dim sideâchapel, no bright glow
From jewelled windows on the wall was shed;
No sunbeams rested on the font below,
Or kissâd those mighty arches overhead.
Soft lines and curves went upward, and were lost
In solemn shadow and in dreamy space;
Only the level floor was faintly crost
With glimmering brightness from the holy place.
And, as I listenâd, I heard music sweet
Trembling and swelling through the soundless air,
Threading dark aisles, as if an angelâs feet
Were bidden bring Godâs message to me there.
Ah! and the echo of those anthem notes
Wanders and whispers in my heart for aye:
In all my life the mystic language floats,
Fitful and faint, as in my ears that day.
One whom we knew had enterâd into restâ
Calm on the pillow lay his hoary head;
And through that music spoke, in accents blest,
Our holy Motherâs voice, hallowing the dead,
Telling of perfect peace, of labours done,
Of long yearsâ sorrow turned to joy at lastâ
The quiet sleep, when battles all are wonâ
The hush of evening when the day is past.
I lookâd upon the font, and mused of all
Its wondrous meaning, till my thoughts grew dim
And vast and shadowy as those columns tall;â
Morning of life for meâdeathâs night for him!
How fancy tried to span that awful space
